production, whose effects are not even calculable today, in the name of an abstract consistency for a theoretical model of market liberalism, of total respect for competition, as some voices have been heard even today, or to take responsibility for adequately addressing the situation.

There remains an urgency to approve this package at first reading at the December plenary session, as expected by European citizens.

Thank you, Mr President. For future reference, if the future has a memory, we are witnessing a genetic mutation of that Parliament and that European Union, Mr President.

No, it's not like that. As a politician, I don't act on behalf of corporations or unions. I act on behalf of citizens.
I think of them when I make a choice, I think of their social rights which are fundamental to me in Europe.

And this is all the more serious at a time when Europe is experiencing its worst crisis and sees no prospects for prosperity and growth.

Thank you, Mr President. We are facing an important compromise for Europe, even if the European Parliament has had to swallow a few bitter pills.
In substance, the text on renewables that emerged from the trialogue contains a clear definition of the objectives and, above all, of their mandatory nature.
The 2014 review clause is intended to provide greater flexibility in order to achieve the remaining 20% reduction target and, if conditions permit, to push for a 30% reduction by 2020.

It should be emphasized that the most powerful and economically advantageous flexibility tool for Member States lies in national efficiency measures in the building, transport, and industrial sectors, as well as in the better use of electricity.
The mandatory 10% target for biofuels should be qualified with efficiency requirements in the transformation processes, by authorizing environmental and social sustainability criteria,
The use of biomass should be directed towards non-controversial areas, towards conversion technologies that are more effective than first and second generation biofuels.
The agreement reached by the Council and the will of the European Parliament send a positive message. One cannot tackle the serious economic crisis without changes in strategy.
Those who, like Berlusconi, mocked the European directives, the 320, calling them a quixotic plan, have been defeated.

The package that this Parliament is called upon to approve, despite the watering down due to the selfishness of the Member States, is moving in the direction of providing innovative responses to alleviate the impact of climate change.
If we do not act quickly, this problem will weigh more heavily on the European economy, but above all on the lives of European citizens.
Mr President, Commissioner, I am very grateful first and foremost to the Chairman of the European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture, my colleague Mr Parish, for
I have tabled this question following the important hearing of experts we held in the committee itself.
It is undeniable that the Mediterranean diet is part of the historical and cultural heritage of our continent, just as its health-promoting principles are undeniable.
The same Commission, in its white paper against obesity, identified it as an absolutely suitable natural medicine.
The health benefits are scientifically proven and enjoy widespread popularity abroad, starting with the United States.
And so it happens that the concept expands to the point of distorting its originality.
This is why the recognition by UNESCO establishes a definition to protect this peculiarity. And I want to say to my colleague Parish that
Today, due to the peculiarities of European gastronomic culture, we are talking about Mediterranean cuisine, but certainly not as the only peculiarity of the richness of European gastronomy.
Commissioner, you have upheld your predecessor's commitment to recognizing the importance of this initiative, and for that I thank you.
He emphasized that he has no decision-making power within the UNESCO procedure, however I think he will be able to make a pronouncement, a statement.

President, let's start with a concept: the Mediterranean diet, as confirmed by numerous studies, promotes the fight against obesity and cardiovascular diseases and is generally very positive for human health in many aspects.

But the point here is not to claim that the Mediterranean diet should be imposed throughout the EU or to attempt to favor it over other dietary regimens that are better suited to different climates and regions outside the Mediterranean.
However, we have the task of protecting it, defining its content and characteristics, in order to defend it from imitations and external contaminations that could damage its image and value.
It should therefore be valued, like all other European cultural expressions, which deserve to be defended and promoted globally.

It is a model that the world tries to copy. It is therefore important to specify its peculiarities and safeguard it, to prevent a completely European heritage from being lost in the sea of globalization.

The crisis in the automotive sector has become a crisis for an entire industry, affecting the ancillary industries of other related sectors, commercial networks, and consequently services, and it offers a grim outlook in terms of employment.

I think that the dramatic decline in these latest enrollments, which is said to be as much as 33% less in some member countries, 20% less in others, etc., for this month, demonstrates that this is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector, nor does it originate within the sector itself, nor within this or that company due to managerial errors.
It is a systemic crisis and as such must be addressed urgently and decisively by the European institutions themselves.
Some remedies seem to be identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources, with what prospects for innovation.
Demand must certainly be supported. Consumption is the only driver of recovery.

But in the meantime, while this response of supporting consumption is being implemented, which is a medium-term response, I think we need to say that there is an immediate need for credit support to resume production, pay for materials, and support employment, even in the face of a decline in orders and demand.
So the credit sector, but as we said, the how is important.
And I too call here for a stronger role for Europe. It is important that the European institutions send out a signal.

America is intervening, some European countries are doing so, I too hope that my country will move from generic proposals to concrete initiatives, but I hope there will be stronger European action in the recovery plan and beyond the recovery plan.

Because I think, and our commissioner has also said it in some ways, that the fate of the large European companies is a common fate and the large European producers must not find competition within the commercial market.

This is common in the form of various forms of state aid or incentives, but they must find a strong, incisive and coordinated response from Europe, because the fate of the European car market is measured by the ability to face global competition together.

And there is the other point that was mentioned, Sacconi said it, and I will reiterate it: support should not be an aid or, worse, a rescue that leaves everything as it is, but an incentive for a fundamental competitive capacity.

Thank you, Mr President, dear colleagues. I thank the blind presidency, the Commission, the Chairman of the Energy and Industry Committee, Mr Nibbler, and the regular colleagues.

I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteurs of this energy package, the shadow rapporteurs, and the Commission secretariat for the collaboration and expertise they have demonstrated on this dossier.
We can and must all be proud of the result achieved. I am proud, thinking about the effort made when I inherited the directive on the internal gas market, with problems that were not easy to solve.

I am pleased to have coincided my second experience as a European deputy with the final phase of this package, which I consider to be among the most important dossiers of this legislative term in favor of our European citizens, our voters.
The gas directive, which will come into force starting in 2011, introduces significant innovations in the sector. It is important to highlight the achievement of option I as a major result.
which ensures the opening of markets and real progress towards a system that truly allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy matters.
The OTI is the real innovation in this package and it is the one on which the European Parliament can be said to have achieved the best result.
The new gas directive gives a lot of importance to the gas authority and the agency.
This directive legitimizes the authorities in their role, particularly in those countries where they must start their work from scratch.

Therefore, it is of fundamental importance to have designed the role and competences of these bodies, to have given them broad powers, since it falls to the authorities the difficult task of controlling the common energy market.

Another element that was added during the trilogue phase is the exemption from the common rules of so-called closed systems, i.e., airports, hospitals, railway stations, industrial sites, etc., for the
This is a particular peculiarity of theirs. They are subject to a more favorable regime, which demonstrates the attention that the new directive pays to the needs of the European citizen.

In my opinion, it is the European citizen who will truly benefit from this directive, as they will have access to all information related to their bill through the use of smart meters, allowing them to evaluate the best offer on the market and choose their supplier freely.

This is due to convenience. Because while it is true that it will take years to see the effects of this liberalization, it is undeniable that the entry of new operators into the market will lead to lower prices and more favorable market conditions for EU citizens.
Another important element is the recognition of European transmission network systems, which will ensure the security of gas supply to European citizens.
This also involves the reinforcement and creation of new infrastructure, such as regulators and storage facilities, which will be the driving force behind the third package.
Therefore, a competitive market is required to ensure long-term investments and contracts from companies in the sector.
This is particularly true in the new member countries, where the creation of new infrastructure would also help to solve long-standing problems of dependence.
The protection of the most vulnerable consumers was taken into account, giving the national and regional authorities the possibility to guarantee their gas supply during the most critical moments.
The successful outcome of the gas directive and the entire energy package once again highlights the role of Europe and its institutions for European citizens.

once we find ourselves in this Chamber to defend a food, cultural, and rural heritage stemming from a centuries-old tradition, an invaluable heritage that the world envies us, which represents an enormous wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our Union.

A heritage that today risks finding itself in serious difficulty due to the Commission's and Council's desire to abolish the Coupage ban for the production of ros wines, a desire born under strong pressure.

pressure and will be ratified without the possibility of intervention by Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, both producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

As the sponsor of the question, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our products, which are the result of centuries of tradition and research, of extremely important investments, and of passion,

and attention to detail is not the answer we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this, when the average consumer is definitely more concerned about the price than about a label on the product.

Thank you. Mr President, first of all, allow me to greet the Chairman of the DTP Party, Mr Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the front row and is following the debate.
Dear Ahmet, know that we stand in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle that your party is waging in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize the DTP as an indispensable tool for promoting democracy in Turkey and for this reason we firmly condemn the police operations that the
Prime Minister Erdogan has ordered against you, imprisoning all three vice-presidents of the DTP along with over 300 militants and sympathizers.
The DTP's victory in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more imprisonment.
Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the left in Europe have so far supported Turkey's accession process to the European Union, while also supporting the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in the last two years, and especially in recent months, Erdogan has shown another side, that of a leader compromised with the worst part of the Turkish army, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds. Erdogan himself is closing any prospect of Turkey's accession.
It is his and his alone the responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish question a priority, which, let it be clear, goes through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to ask for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

Turkey's path to EU membership goes through Diyarbakir and the DTP; otherwise, it will be we, those who have so far supported the accession process, who will call for a period of reflection that risks being definitive.

Thank you, Mr President, I would like to thank the Council for sharing the principles and, if I may say so, Commissioner Barroco, with whom I had a very productive dialogue that was extremely useful in the work we then presented in the Chamber.

but I believe that the work we have done allows us to be optimistic.

of people who are at risk of dying in the coming years due to prior exposure, however. The latency period, we know, can be as long as 15 and even 20 years. They don't count for anything at all.

Today, the industry is asking the Commission to once again tolerate an exception, already granted for a limited time by the Rich regulation in 2006, for chrysotile asbestos fiber.

It is true, they have a limited application to low-voltage electrolysis plants and only in a few plants, but where industrialists claim the impossibility of any alternative substitute as soon as the plants are closed.

A racket, but an alternative to this process has been found in Sweden, using technologies for the replacement of asbestos-free membranes for low voltage, and a similar solution has also been adopted for hydrogen production.

Why, as in the long battle to ban PCBs, were there so many omissions and hesitations to act, even endorsed by the Enterprise DG of the European Commission?
Once again, a good example was not set.
The 1999 directive banning asbestos required that the review of this authorization be preceded by an opinion from the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, which was never produced.

Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, it is not my intention, nor that of my group, which supported and wanted this debate, to transfer Italian internal political issues to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all, it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at a Community level, in order to counteract political and economic conditioning and to guarantee a real pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous intertwining of media, political, and economic powers.

This is precisely why we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, serves to protect the pluralism of information, preventing concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we are asking the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Thank you, Mr President. I am aware that on 30 September last, the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report was voted on, with Marianne Micco as rapporteur, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect, and I quote verbatim, the multiplicity
of opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diversified information media.

And even earlier, in 2004, a report was voted on in Parliament, with Bogert-Quack as rapporteur, on the risks of violation in the European Union of freedom of expression and information, which called on the Commission to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear answers to Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but as a European citizen here, I ask you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Thank you.

Honorable President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the Middle East peace process.
We saw the hopeful smiles of the Palestinian representatives.

It has been intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the window bars of their homes, on a street in Hebron, the ghost street that cannot be crossed by any Palestinian.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her occupied home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent placed in the garden of what used to be her home. The suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funds, only to have it destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, and a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the last day of the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the delegation from the European Parliament, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this issue, High Representative Baroness Ashton must intervene to make the protest of democratic Europe heard.

I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation because during the days we were in Palestine, the weak in Palestine were able to see and hear the face and words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honorable colleagues, the topic of tax good governance, while always being of great importance, has taken on even greater relevance and significance after the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International, G20 and European leaders have discussed this issue and continue to do so, particularly when addressing the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All of this is important, it is a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not delude oneself into thinking that an announcement is enough.
A serious and continuous policy is needed.
There are still many problems.
It is still too easy to buy or set up a shell company to evade taxes.
Just take a look on the Internet. There are thousands of sites offering companies for sale, even in European Union countries.
and often all it takes is an email with a scanned photocopy of the passport attached to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be stopped.
This report that I am presenting is based on the European Commission's communication on tax good governance of 28 April 2009.
The report aims to put forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and illicit capital flight must be considered a priority of the European Union.
Hence the principle of good governance, which is based on transparency, exchange of information, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a need for ever greater tax cooperation and collaboration in the European Union.
The overall goal we must set for ourselves is to achieve an automatic exchange of information on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, with the European Union.
As my colleague Alvarez has already said, we must abolish bank secrecy altogether in European Union countries and put an end to the derogation regime without further delay.
a temporary measure that authorizes the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in place of the exchange of information.
I do not wish to dwell on the concrete proposals contained in the report.
I would like to emphasize that we still need a few specific points. Expanding the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combating VAT fraud, and establishing a public European Union register.
which takes into account individuals or companies that have set up companies or opened accounts in tax havens. Reconfirm and relaunch tax harmonization projects starting with

from the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. The European Union must also speak with a single voice internationally, advocating for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic exchange of information instead of exchange upon request.

We will hold the Council and the Commission accountable for their work.

I must admit that when we talk about fighting terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we are examining the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not time to address the problem of terrorism by targeting the heart of the issue rather than merely focusing on its external phenomenology?

Tackling the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder and I ask this Parliament, do we want to discuss terrorism?
So let this Parliament have the courage to engage in a political debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full veil, to encourage this House to openly confront the issue.
It seems that there is no will whatsoever to address the issue.
I wonder, and I ask you, honorable colleagues from all political groups, if not on these topics, on which others should the political war of the peoples of Europe pronounce itself?

Thank you, Mr President. The conclusion of negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is a feasible goal, and the Svoboda report highlights in a balanced manner the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now it is the justice sector that still requires incisive reforms.
And it is not enough, in fact, to complete the necessary systemic reforms, approve new laws, and cooperate as needed with the Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a genuine legal culture and mentality in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, a central issue, the training, recruitment, and career development of magistrates, and the absence of various types of government influence on judges become crucial.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Thank you, Mr. President. Croatia's accession to the European Union accentuates the consolidation of a European identity, capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe without obscuring, but rather integrating the specificities of its many souls.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in adapting to the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with the provisions of the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed in Paris in 1952, by considering the restitution of nationalized property to its rightful owners.
President, once again recently in Italy there has been an environmental disaster, the Lambro River and the Po River.

It's an ongoing environmental disaster.

The European Court of Justice has severely condemned Italy for its failure to manage waste in Campania. The city of Naples has been exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and months around the world.

We want to firmly tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, has a duty of consistency today, if it does not want to lose credibility.
must do everything possible to ensure that these objectives are achieved.

I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligences are ready, the capabilities are there, the will is there; it is now a matter of turning on this engine.
Everyone has to do it, said the Commissioner, said the Council. The Member States, the entrepreneurs, the private forces have to do it.

To address the employment problem in a constructive way, the key words for community relations are three: react, evolve, and protect.

React, that is, abandon the celebratory tones of Euro-propaganda to address in a concrete way the problems that afflict EU citizens, ensuring a direct link between the world of training and the needs of the market and the territory, requalifying in young people the perception of manual professions.

To evolve, or rather, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market where the flexibility of contractual forms responds to the instabilities of market demand.

Protect, that is, give work to those who have lost it, first and foremost to our citizens. The Member States must therefore assess immigration policies based on the real need for immigration. And with 23 million unemployed, we should consider the possibility of blocking extra-Community immigration for a few years.
I see no other way to protect our jobs and our social system.
What is needed is concreteness, courage and decentralization.

Yes, Mr President, I would like to stress once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other Members of Parliament and that more than half of the European Parliament approved, in order to commit the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I returned on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control from a visit to Greece and it is certain that one of the reasons for the Greek structural crisis is also due to the squandering of public money, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Corruption is corroded by corruption, as is evident these days, corruption that primarily revolves around the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a segment of politics and a segment of entrepreneurs, and white-collar organized crime.

Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues, Commissioner. Today we find ourselves discussing organ transplantation, which undoubtedly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare sector.
but on the other hand, it opens up a whole series of problems regarding the rights of the donor and the patient that need to be addressed on an ethical, social, legal, and economic level.

It is a matter of activating a virtuous path that addresses the serious imbalance between the need for and quantity of available organs, without however undermining the principle of free and voluntary donation, thus preventing
all forms of commercialization and illegal trafficking, ensuring the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that balance confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplant systems adopted in the various Member States, these objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be very important to establish a European deeds bank and adopt common quality and security standards.
We must be careful, however, not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create additional bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently being done correctly and effectively.

Thank you, Mr President. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work carried out on the European Union's accession to the Convention on Human Rights.

This is a benefit for European citizens, because it will result in a new external court to the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and its member states.

By virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its member states must always have the right to defend themselves. For this reason, I believe it is essential that every nation that adheres to the Convention should have a judge who explains the context of each appeal. Just as I consider it important

it is important that the European Parliament has an informal body for the purpose of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is also important that the Parliament is consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, just as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I believe it is essential that the Council of Europe and the European Union consider developing guidelines with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that the decision will entail.

On immigration, the program, beyond the official documents, displays an embarrassing nobility. What is the point of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if there is then a lack of a political strategy?

A truly useful strategy that must be based on some fundamental points: combating illegal immigration along the southern border, sharing responsibility among all European states and UN agencies in the fight against illegal immigration, a policy of agreements with third countries, and above all, recognizing that immigration is not a resource during times of crisis.
On the Parliament's homepage we read that more than 20% of young people in Europe are unemployed.

Instead, we must think in concrete and realistic terms. Today, the priority is to give work to our citizens. Everything else is feel-good rhetoric that does not help either the integration of immigrants or our people.

Thank you, Mr President. Honourable colleagues, as we know, the European Parliament has been called upon to express its final opinion on food information for consumers.
It should be immediately noted that this was an objectively laborious, lengthy, and controversial legislative process that could not be shortened.

The aim is indeed to harmonise Community law on foodstuffs through regulations designed to make information transparent to consumers, avoiding misleading choices that could potentially harm their health.

The report by Mr Sommer, who deserves credit for his efforts to summarise the various requirements, therefore aims to remedy the controversial and diverse information systems currently in place in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations to date differ in the designations of the nature of foods placed on sale, generating a different system from country to country, and also fueling unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
An attempt was thus made, based on the proposal of the European Commission, to give new life to the current legislation, involving both the food industry and consumers.
At the same time, the report commits the European food industry to clarify mandatory indications and the presentation of food and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not avoid adapting and innovating its food product legislation, in order to better protect food trade and safeguard against increasingly invasive and fierce international competition.

It is not new that one hears more often about the perversity of food products, which are over-processed and have a nomenclature with indications that often do not meet food requirements, which are nevertheless marketed as food and beneficial for human health.
