contribute to the autobiographical reflection on their experiences, on what they have learned to respond to the challenges that Europe is presenting in positive terms.

As you can see, Mr President, Commissioner, we intend to introduce something new into the tradition of the courses that have been held up to now and which we believe have been ineffective for this purpose.

We will need to know how much funding is available and what kind, and express doubt about the idea of how it was written in the communication from a central European institution to govern this process, because we are in favor of a grassroots movement rather than centralization.
This is a new approach

What we mean, however, is that if a European mentality is not formed among magistrates and lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and to the citizens who demand it, we will not make Europe.
So this is not just an important card for European justice, it is an important card for the entire development of European unity.
Thank you, Mr. President. The proposal on the rights of passengers traveling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should guarantee passengers the same rights as in the rail and air sectors.
The position at second reading aims to establish a set of rights for passengers who choose to travel by bus,

I agree with the line taken by the rapporteur, Mr Cancian, whom I thank for the excellent work he has done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and proper to guarantee passengers' rights in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays in departure, as had already been decided at first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the issue of information on passengers' rights. It would be useful, in fact, to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and those by rail.

With regard to disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility, it is necessary to guarantee maximum protection, and I would propose a deadline of 24 hours instead of 48 for requesting assistance, as well as greater guarantees for compensation and replacement of mobility aids in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure should be improved to make them accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all to improve the travel conditions for passengers.

Thank you, Mr President. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sterks, who has done an excellent job on this report, which deals with extending the free movement of seafarers for navigation within the European Union.
I agree with the rapporteur on the purpose of this directive, which is to exempt all maritime transport of goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, in order to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make the transport of goods by sea more attractive and to be used in an optimal manner.

The harmonization of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed on it.
Electronic systems should therefore come into operation as quickly as possible, because it would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Moreover, interoperability is important for achieving real administrative simplification. In fact, the transmission of information via email is not entirely efficient and is useless if the information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation,
This would make communication faster, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Yes, thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to extend my special congratulations to our rapporteur, Mr. Kramer, because we all know that we have truly achieved a result that sometimes seemed unexpected.
I would like to remind you that this dossier was considered to be at real risk of conciliation proceedings.
So we have also heard from the Commissioner's words, it is evident to all that we are facing a job that has been complex and has taken a long time.
Suffice it to say that a 1996 directive is involved, and this work brings us to the fifth and most important amendment to the industrial emissions directive.
I believe that these few data points alone tell us everything about the shortcomings and even the flaws of this legislation.

A directive that is difficult to implement, I would like to remind you that nine member states are affected by infringement procedures and with a scope so extensive that it is sometimes even inappropriate.

Let us not hide the fact that all of this has involved considerable effort, required sacrifices from all the institutions involved, from all the political groups, from all the national delegations, and has often placed us before truly difficult choices.

But I am here this evening to say with conviction that in my opinion we have achieved the best possible result in terms of protecting competition, the environment, and European industrial and employment policy.
On the one hand, we have a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand, we also have a directive that allows for the necessary flexibility.

I truly hope that the results of this recast will be the immediate reduction of administrative burdens and, in the medium term, the improvement of environmental performance and the strengthening of the European industry.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to emphasize the situation in which the Church is facing a reality that for too long has not been given the importance it deserves.

That is to say the instability in Central Asia that unfortunately is growing while the hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

Kirchner has suffered in the past month from extremely harsh clashes that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatreds that will make the stabilization of the country even more difficult than it was before.
The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been said, is to assist Kikisda in every possible way in three areas. Through immediate aid for the
emergency supplies for the reconstruction of destroyed homes. Secondly, through economic aid of the longest possible duration, in the case of the European Union, within the framework of the

strategy for the central area and the instruments implemented in this context, through political support to back the process of returning to constitutional legality and the establishment of a genuine rule of law.

The constitutional referendum, which was also held in a state of crisis since June 28, under obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road back to a constitutional order.

The electoral process on June 28, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE observation mission, which obviously took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of Cristian will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than towards a presidential system.
This may perhaps allow for a better consideration of the country's diverse ethnic composition and the need to gather consensus from the various components of such a fragmented and complex country.
The European Union and CRIS are bound by a partnership and cooperation agreement that provides for regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation committee.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a Parliament that is democratically elected, the Chiso.
In the immediate term, as already mentioned, the crisis needs stability and our political and economic help. Let's try not to be stingy with both.
European Council that no one voted for. Today we also have a rotating presidency in the hands of a government that has been dismissed by its own citizens.

This alone would be enough to understand why Europe is experiencing a profound crisis, an Europe that has now become a political paradox in the hands of a political elite that the citizens do not know.
The Belgian non-presidency program talks about structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability and competitiveness, and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should push Europe towards very different ingredients from those that led to failure.

A general rethinking is necessary, because the crisis is not a reflection of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that Euro-propaganda would instead like to administer as a cure.
Today Europe is an immense building that is collapsing in on itself under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary. More decentralization, less bureaucracy, more concreteness and attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inevitably accelerate the decline.
Mr President, thank you, I apologise. I would like to emphasise in this speech how the progressive erosion of European farmers' incomes at the expense of increasing

The profit margins of the agro-industrial chain are creating a worrying economic marginalization of those working in the agricultural sector, resulting in the abandonment of the very activities they are engaged in.
A change of direction is therefore necessary, which the European Commission itself acknowledges and which the report under examination by the House this morning,
The approval of the Chamber this morning, to which I wish to express my support, emphasizes with ample reasons and suggestions of a legislative and departmental nature.
It is indeed necessary to fight against global speculation on raw materials and ensure the security of supplies.

Moreover, better price transparency must be ensured, which not only gives justice and dignity to farmers, but also corrects the strong imbalances in bargaining power and abusive debts among the different operators.
Agriculture must reaffirm itself as a sector of economic and social stability and gain power in the European Union's commercial context.
Mobilism and myopia: this is the diagnosis of the malaise affecting Europe 27 today.

The stagnation is also due to the fact that, despite the euro-propaganda of recent months, no concretely effective action has followed. In Italy, one in four young people is unemployed, and in the eurozone, there are 16 million unemployed people.

The shortcoming lies in the fact that Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, has not only presented the same old recipe, but has completely lost sight of the most self-evidently territorial dimension of the policy of economic and social cohesion.

Only by placing the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment restart, drawing nourishment from the natural energies expressed by each geographical area, districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and craftsmanship.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small, invest in local entities, and prioritize sustainability by protecting a heritage made up of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the needle of the European compass does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Europroject is a certainty.
Thank you, Mr. President. In the construction of a Europe of rights, a central place is occupied by freedom of information, pluralism of information, and the independence of information.
Did Commissioner Sir, Commissioner Madam, notice that there is a country in the European Union, which was also a founder of the European Union with the Treaty of Rome, where there is no
a pluralism of information, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls both public and private television and the press.
What kind of democratic electoral competition can there be in a country where a Prime Minister and a political party control the media?
What kind of democracy can exist in a country where they want to pass a law within days that does not allow journalists to publish judicial news?
Anything but Watergate, anything but a Guardian of the Regime press, a lapdog. What kind of democratic country is it where the internet is to be brought under control?
What kind of democratic country is it where those who oppose the dominant ideology are sidelined and the free expression of thought and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing the Sudan of Bocassa or the Romania of Ceausescu and the Italy of Berlusconi, where unfortunately this happens also because the European Commission does not have the courage to express an autonomous and free position with respect to the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but it would be...

It would be appropriate for the Commission to conduct an impact assessment, as some colleagues before me have pointed out, of the opening up of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas, such as mountainous or rural regions, to receive their mail regularly, and what instruments does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure this happens?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used to justify the problem of social dumping.
It is the Member States that must implement the directive and they have all the tools to do so.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. Today's debate on readmission agreements cannot avoid the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that one side of the agreement is focused on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because so far the Commission has told us little about it, despite the Lisbon Treaty requiring the Commission itself to promptly inform Parliament.
As is well known, Libya has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it demonstrated any behavior in line with international law to date.

I think of the case of the Eritrean immigrants, held inhumanely in the Libyan center of Brak, or the closure of the UNHCR offices. But I think above all of what happened last week, when a Libyan Republic patrol boat opened fire.

against an Italian fishing boat from the Marina di Mazzara del Vallo present in international waters, with the justification of the presence on board of illegal immigrants. A very serious justification that makes us think that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy that

It also provides for the deportation of immigrants to Libya without provisions for the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examination of individual situations. It also includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Since part of the agreement is secret in this case as well, I wonder if the Commission is aware of its content. If it does not consider it necessary, in this specific case, to ask for explanations, the merits

to the possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on boats if there is a suspicion that they are transporting irregular immigrants, because if that were the case, it would be among the provisions

From an economic standpoint, it is positive for Europe to deepen trade relations with neighboring countries that are experiencing strong growth. However, the EU has always conducted, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries that takes into account social and humanitarian aspects.

We must therefore assert these clauses with firm determination in relation to Turkey, a country that is re-Islamizing, where the condition of women is gradually deteriorating, with more than 1,500 women.
women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence. A country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists. One need only recall the brutal murder of Monsignor Padovanese.

In the report, Parliament encourages Turkey to take a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain, we must be concerned about the political leadership role that Turkey is trying to carve out for itself in the Arab world and the

The friendship Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups like Hamas. Anyway, if it has to be trade policy, so be it. But this should never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, Commissioner, this measure aims to strengthen and rationalise the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious objectives set out in the reports in Meccheva, which respectively amend Regulation 726 and Directive 2183.
Thanks to close and efficient collaboration between the Council and the European Parliament, and the relevant parliamentary committees, it has been possible to
Today we will discuss a proposal aimed at improving the Community pharmacovigilance system and refining the European Union's consistent and long-standing activity in this sector.

Simplification, transparency and rationalisation can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health based on standards harmonised throughout Europe.

In fact, reference is made to a wide range of interventions ranging from a better definition of the roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational stakeholders, to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient, to which...

recognizes a fundamental role of the actor in the system in strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicinal products, simplifying the activities of communication, registration and evaluation of alleged negative side effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also thanks to closer collaboration at European, national and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three levels will indeed ensure a fruitful exchange of information regarding adverse drug reactions.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information for the benefit of patients, national authorities and healthcare professionals.
Thank you, Mr. President. Just in these days here in Brussels, the

Many representatives of municipalities and regions have discussed how to address the serious problems that affect the life of our cities, the old and new needs that concern workers, families, and small and large production companies.
The economic crisis that has befallen our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to provide adequate responses to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that the cohesion policy has often been the only concrete tool available to the territories to attempt to provide answers.
Thus, we can say that the cohesion policy has been, in recent years, an essential lever for the process of European integration for all regions.
We are now in the process of redefining this policy for the post-2013 period. We are therefore at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
The first fundamental one is that of its renationalization. It would be a serious step backwards.

Then, when constructing the funding budget, it is necessary to ensure that there is an adequate provision for both the weaker regions and, at the same time, the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify the procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to make the ability to impose sanctions more binding for those who have not.
We expect the Commission to go in this direction.
Honorable colleagues, the road to a woman-friendly Europe is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak for themselves. The global crisis has hit the job market hard, putting a strain on female employment, which in 2008 decreased by a further 0.7 percentage points.

Despite the provocations on the topic of equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a Euro-propaganda in decline of consensus, to date no concrete measures have been adopted to guarantee women true fulfillment as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not just periodically change the label.

The directive aligning maternity leave in Europe is therefore a good thing, but the decision to deal with the complementary and equally important issue of paternity leave on the margins of this matter, in the same report, is inefficient.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value, but also a strategic goal for the sustainability of the much-publicized European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to the lack of results.
Thank you, I will start again. Thank you, Mr President. The rapporteur for the Committee on Development, Mr Mitchell, asked me to replace him because he cannot be present today.

I thank him for the work he has done, with his usual punctuality, and for the quality of his proposals, which have received the favorable opinions, I would say unanimous, of the Development Committee.
Based on what I will say, but especially on what my colleague Michel has done so far, I am convinced that the report can be voted on with a large majority.
But I now come to the report.
In the course of 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905 of 2006, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had asked Parliament to approve an amendment that would allow non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
proposal accepted by us.
But the Cooperation and Development Regulation also contains the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission is to allocate funding, it is required to follow comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine this proposed funding and, in the event that the Commission exceeds its powers, Parliament can then adopt resolutions to request the Commission to change the decisions in question.

Only since 2006 has the Parliament deemed that the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers in at least 12 cases, but in only three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its proposed decision.
Following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Committee on Development proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Lisbon Treaty.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Lisbon Treaty, in certain well-defined cases, Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions. But what could these decisions be?
In our opinion, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

it is a choice that falls to the legislator. And so which sectors should then be given priority in funding? Education? Health? Environmental protection? The capacity for good governance? The development of small businesses?
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the areas where the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislator must provide precise guidance to the executive.
And this is precisely the direction in which, I believe, the demands of European citizens are ultimately heading.
I sincerely hope for the greatest possible consensus on this report by Mr. Mitchell.
to the rapporteur on policy

Integrated maritime policy must move beyond the stage of good intentions and give new impetus to a strategy that will act as a driver for growth and development in the European Union, making up for the enormous delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, the fight against climate change, and the battle against pollution.
This very morning our colleague Pirillo reminded Parliament of yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, in Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate its commitment by not only using governance tools, but also implementing specific legislative measures, learning from past mistakes that were often due to an overly sectoral approach.

There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and challenging endeavor that cannot afford any lack of attention and that requires adequate investment and

participatory governance mechanisms, both at the inter-institutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out due to the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will therefore be essential to understand the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage to all the coastal states, based on the principle of the

On the other hand, the increasingly widespread practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar areas in the Mediterranean Sea, besides not being in line with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the idea of effective and shared governance.

I would like to remind you in this regard that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya led to an actual armed assault on a European fishing boat, and it would be wrong to claim that this is an exclusively Italian-Libyan issue.

Thank you, Mr President. I would like to thank Mrs Meissner for her report on the integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding, protect coastal regions, and promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sector.
For this reason, cooperation should be encouraged between small and large ports that face the same sea basin and can facilitate a more fluid commercial exchange.
Moreover, to ensure intermodality, investment is needed in port and hinterland infrastructure, especially in ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely that of port security.

There needs to be a homogenization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, in order to guarantee greater security, must incur higher expenses.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thirty years ago, Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people. Today, it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in Western Sahara there are dead and wounded from a population that claims only the right to live in freedom in their own land.
Morocco has essentially closed its borders to anyone who might witness these events.
No information and no deputies.
access was denied to a French MP and our colleague Meyer.
Europe watches passively.
There is no sign of the Commission's communication that makes us subordinate to UN mediation, which continues to fail as it has for the past thirty years.
There is no statement from Mrs. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
A response is needed in the form of a parliamentary resolution.
Action must be taken against Morocco by halting all initiatives on trade agreements, starting with the renewal of the fisheries agreements.

Thank you, Mr. President. My speech is not intended to be the usual rhetorical and skeptical exercise, but an impulse that begins to focus more on the content than the container and abandons propaganda in favor of concreteness.
Having failed with the Lisbon strategy, Europe has agreed on the new EU 2020 slogan, but in reality it has not provided any innovative solutions to employment problems.

The data confirms it. The unemployment rate in Europe is 9.6%, and the youth unemployment rate is 20.2%. In Italy, the third largest net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of young people without a job.

In the Europe I would like to see, there is no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments so that the educational offerings prepare professionals for the sectors of the internal market, where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of the excellence of our regions.
The world of craftsmanship offers a potential for employment and a unique wealth of knowledge, to which the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system must be entrusted.

Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Madam President of the Council. The European will to set ambitious goals in view of the upcoming climate change conference is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

The international negotiations leading up to the Cancun conference, as far as we know, have not only failed to make appreciable progress towards a global agreement, but have also confirmed the distrust and resistance to the commitments made in Copenhagen.
It has already been mentioned, but I would also like to mention China here.
China, for example, is allowing its emissions to increase by 5 billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset
and perhaps not even that, but an attempt at compensation with only a 100% reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only renders the proposal of an unconditional 30% reduction, which we strongly oppose, as unrealistic, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

Here, in this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least risky and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and outline appealing but unrealistic scenarios where the unknowns inevitably reflect on the cost dimension.
It is hoped that the European Union will bring a shared, realistic and sustainable proposal to Cancun, because an agreement that delivers concrete and perceptible results is always preferable to

inevitably doomed to failure and increasingly discrediting in the eyes of public and international opinion, this would indeed be a difficult damage to repair, the efforts of governments on major environmental issues.

Thank you, Mr. President. I have only one regret in this hall tonight, that we are discussing the Sarawis only because the Moroccans have invaded the Tent City outside and the IUN. And this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
Parliament should have matured the will to discuss this issue that has been festering on international tables for 30 years.
This is the most significant political fact.
We were forced by acts of violence, not because we autonomously decided to ensure human rights.
Because what is it if not respect for human rights, the fact that there should be a referendum on self-determination there?
It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strong point of our relations. We must demand forcefully, with all the necessary actions, that there be an irrefutable will.
We must try to build the conditions so that the Minuso mission, Mr. President, is not alone in building the conditions for a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must try to use all the means at the disposal of the European Union to influence this event and to ensure that the referendum does justice to 30 years of suffering of a people.
Mr President, apart from this issue, I wanted to raise a problem with the Presidency.
I believe that some people still do not fully understand the role of the European Parliament after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am forced to raise a fundamental issue here. Transport Commissioner Callas repeatedly refuses to meet with the Sky and Space board to discuss the Cesar project, which is of interest to everyone from an economic, environmental, and safety perspective.
I call on the Presidency to summon Commissioner Callas to the chamber and to explain what programme he intends to pursue in this extremely sensitive and important sector for the European Parliament.

The report and discussion certainly contain positive elements. The general orientation is towards simplifying procedures and streamlining bureaucratic steps for workers from third countries with a valid residence permit in a Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to remind you that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are without work due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and the effects of a crisis that shows no sign of ending.

Even before taking care of citizens from third countries who reside in our countries, Europe should primarily focus on implementing economic, political, and social measures that help our citizens find or regain employment.
If Europe can provide jobs for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations to properly accommodate migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first and foremost, to make Europe grow on its own legs and with its own strength.
our countries will then have the strength
Thank you, Mr. President. To date, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of third-country nationals.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must take action to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals who reside legally within the Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or persons in need of international protection, in accordance with Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example, for seasonal workers just because they are paid less or because they have different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

For example, we must avoid the risk that many multinational companies will move their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees and self-employed workers should be included in this directive.
drawing distinctions will become extremely dangerous.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honorable colleagues, according to estimates by international organizations and law enforcement agencies, human trafficking is now the second most profitable source of income for organized crime worldwide, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that around 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against illegal immigration, against crime that generates more crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.

Cooperation between member countries and police forces is necessary in the fight against this phenomenon, but above all, there must be certainty of punishment for traffickers. However, let us remember that many people are discovered.

They are exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions, they live in poverty and despair and are ready to do anything to leave their land in search of the promise of a better life that will never materialize.

Europe, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit itself more and with greater diligence so that these people can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
acceptable. Let's help them at home. This must be the guiding principle of European political action so that our efforts are directed not only at repression, but also at prevention.
Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Lady Aston, esteemed colleagues. As Vice Chairman of the Development Committee, I am engaged with the problems of many countries, especially in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled upon, if not sometimes even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of Congo, where, in addition to the usual institutional meetings, I wanted to meet with representatives of the NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centers where they work.
I must say that they are also working very well. I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a weapon of war, where armed groups continue to
repeatedly commit mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civilian society, especially against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of Congo because it was a very recent experience of mine.
But the appeal I want to make is aimed at the general need for a strong and continuous condemnation against the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly increase funding for initiatives aimed at protecting women from violence and other forms of abuse.
such as, among others, genital mutilation, which is also a serious form of violation of human rights and women's physical integrity.
Thank you, Mr. President. The European Heritage Label is of fundamental importance for a continent that houses the majority of UNESCO sites and is part of a highly significant economy.
finally highlights those natural, archaeological, urban and cultural sites that have played an important role in the history, culture and integration of the European Union.
The approval of the label is an important step for the cohesion process of the Union and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.
It can also be noted that this choice bodes well for the new generations, who will increasingly have a shared vision of the European heritage that can be accumulated historically and culturally.

I must thank the rapporteur for her efforts and extend my warmest congratulations to her for the negotiations conducted with the Commission to ensure the effective success of this initiative, which is so important for the future of territorial preservation.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Azai, are a health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious implications not only for the health of those who suffer from it,
but the costs that must be borne for direct and informal care are indeed high.
Alzheimer's disease, in fact, not only affects the people who are afflicted by it, but also involves all those who care for the patients themselves.

A European response to the problem is therefore necessary, a comprehensive coordination among the Member States, a synergy of concerted actions that primarily involve the scientific and research sector and that take charge of the project.

strengthening prevention, diagnosis, and improvement of available treatments, including innovative ones, as well as the dissemination of information among states on the results achieved within them, leading to incremental increases in citizens' knowledge of the disease.

Thank you, Mr. President. The situation is that Campania, particularly the city of Naples, is unfortunately now universally known worldwide, and the European Union has had to address the issue on several occasions.

Faced with this now paradoxical, third-world situation, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the point of view of Community law, and what economic sanctions will possibly be imposed on Italy in the event that the waste crisis in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I also ask whether the Commission can provide detailed data on the European funds that have so far been managed by the Campania Region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, usually when we talk about an emergency, we are talking about dramatic, extreme situations, which however find a solution within a reasonable timeframe.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, obviously something is not working.

In recent years, the Italian government has tried to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal. But obviously, if the streets of Naples are now overrun with tons of garbage,
tons of garbage, the blame is mainly to be attributed to the local authorities, the Campania authorities, and their total inability or lack of willingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear, and absolutely beyond any doubt, that the conditions in which Naples and Campania find themselves are due to the negligence that has characterized for many years the management of the waste cycle by the municipality, provinces, and regions.
If the duty to separate waste is not fulfilled, which is the first essential element of a functioning waste management plan, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send in the army a few weeks ago, and other times before that, to replace hundreds of sanitation workers who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it obviously cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going very differently, for example in my region, Veneto, where the collection of reference materials has been done for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency fall.

on Campania's politics and local administrators, and above all on the heavy collusion with the mafia, which has always sought and obtained enormous profits from the waste business, thanks to the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local administrations.
The European Union is right to act after the lies of the Berlusconi government, which came to power in 2008 by telling Italians that the waste problem had been solved.
to block funds to Italy until an eco-friendly waste cycle is presented that is based on waste recycling and composting.

And it is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro, which once again relies on uncontrolled landfills like those in Chiaiano, Taverna del Re, and Terzigno, even in the Vesuvius National Park, nor on incinerators that produce death, cancer, or a real health emergency.
Public money in Campania, during the environmental emergency of these 13 years, has consolidated criminal relationships between politics, both left and right, entrepreneurs, and the Camorra.

And environmental issues are resolved by criminalizing dissent, by criminalizing local communities, families, and the territory, as the Italian government has done by using the malganello to suppress those who defend nature and the territory.

International law defines a political refugee as a person who, fearing persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, social membership, or political opinions, finds themselves outside the country of which they are a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecuted person.

Despite the cover provided for years by France, we are talking about a multi-murdering criminal, executor and instigator of four murders, who has hidden behind the pretext of political struggle to escape life imprisonment.
It is disgraceful for a great country to celebrate the denial of the extradition of a criminal who has never repented, by granting them the status of political refugee.
Italian authorities and, above all, the victims' families demand that this criminal be brought to justice.
Faced with President Lula's intransigence on the extradition issue, the EU cannot leave the Italian government to deal with it alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the extradition of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening to suspend cooperation agreements with Brasilia.
provide concrete support to the Tunisian people and its transitional government, in order to relaunch a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been seriously neglected in recent years.
The explosion of anger among the youth and the poor in the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the unequal distribution of wealth and the restrictions on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

North Africa is ablaze, demanding more democracy, more economy, more participation, more jobs, and looks with amazement at the old European continent, immobile and incapable of grasping the social transformations that have taken place in that area and of developing real policies of progress and peace.
Let Europe pay more attention to human rights and democracy, foster more dialogue, more collaboration, and more real economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa in order to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the pushbacks of immigrants and the violent collaboration of countries like Libya. More investments, more hospitality and more aid, more Euro-Mediterranean policy.
History demands it.
The resolution approved today by a majority on the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campania emergency becomes a European emergency and it is a decision in favor of the citizens of Campania.
No to the allocation of funds that simply consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs, and the Camorra. Yes to European money if a credible plan is presented.

environmentally compatible waste management plan, no to uncontrolled landfills in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, yes instead to recycling, to environmentally compatible forms.
and it also says no to the criminalization of dissent by local communities, therefore yes to legality.

It is an important turning point, a warning to the Berlusconi government and to the regional government led by Caldoro, who until now have done nothing but talk and consolidate the cliques and the mafia bourgeoisie.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the problem of falsified medicines is having an increasingly widespread impact at international and Community level, both due to the increase in the number of cases and the improvement in their sophistication.
It is to these challenges that the report by Mr. Mattias seeks to respond, the result of long and laborious negotiations.
The report to which we have expressed our support has defined a regulatory framework that, starting from more precise and detailed definitions, has taken into account
all the players, the moments and the resignations of the pharmaceutical supply chain. Safety, traceability, obligations for the distribution chain, achieving a good compromise.
These are some of the aspects on which it is necessary to work in order to achieve the main objective of establishing stricter rules, in order to prevent entry.
of counterfeit medicines, leading to a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework capable of safeguarding the health of citizens and protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.
Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one with millions of people demanding a fairer distribution of wealth, more justice, protesting against corruption.

From the transition of soldiers and armored vehicles, we must move on to real democracy, a new constitution, new elections, abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights, and freedom.
It will be difficult.
Lurking are those who, in the name of an idea, think they can use any means.
We want to believe in the wonderful Egyptian people, who have never experienced democracy.

We want a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious and political power. A democracy that integrates minorities and realizes true rights, public health, social security, and employment.
Europe should support this path, but invest resources that can promote real development in Egypt. No more dictatorships, no more misery, no more poverty.
President, Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean have, with this measure, entered an even more compelling phase compared to the actions we have taken.
I believe that the act we are enshrining today is much more important than the effects of the 2006 Community regulation.

I think this also addresses some limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has left large sectors of the fishing industry often supporting the idea that yes, Europe does its part, but the other riparian countries do not.
I think it is strategic for us to address the topic in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work carried out by my colleague Rivellini, which I fully support, deserves a formal expression of thanks in this context.
Nevertheless, I have the distinct feeling that the fact that we are unable to resolve this issue at first reading and will proceed to a second reading,
above all on the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation, raises a question. The Parliament on this occasion takes the Commission's side.

Parliament essentially says that it is good that these delegated acts should be the responsibility of the Commission. There is some resistance from the Council. Incidentally, today's absence is also a significant one.
But this act ensures that the idea is ripe in Parliament that maintaining biodiversity, maintaining the fish stocks of this important sea is also the future of fishermen.
But having said that, I think that the phase we are facing must bring back to the fore the idea of codecision.
These delegated acts have a reason for being delegated and therefore conferred today to the Commission, but international agreements must maintain Parliament's role intact when these occur.
Mr President, Commissioner, I believe we have two problems here. One is a methodological problem and the other is a substantive one.

The methodological issue is that we are proceeding through a procedural device, for which we thank Mr Fraga, which is that of the oral question, in order to discuss something that, following the Treaty of Lisbon, should instead be a right of this Parliament.
I think this practice must end. We cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a codecision process.
Codecision is such when it is cultivated in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are having this debate, and when it's over, the treaty will move forward and we will say yes or no in the end.
Well, this method needs to be reconverted.

On the substance, however, I just wanted to emphasize, as I agree with many things said by my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of fisheries agreements, so that they are not just mere commercial agreements through which we go to buy cephalopods for one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

These must be able to measure both sustainability but above all the impact on the economy of that country, understand how many employees are changing, understand what rate of innovation exists for artisanal fishing, understand the use of these resources.
it is not just a simple trade exchange, but a fisheries agreement with all its implications.
Mr President, the vote in favour of Mr Rivasi's motion is the result of an assessment of the management of the H1N1 flu.
which is 2009-2010, which aims to establish general guidelines for conduct that would be valid in any future global health emergencies.
The report, following a long and positive phase of revision, makes cooperation, independence and transparency its main pillars.
It calls for greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and the European institutions, so that a harmonised and coordinated risk management can be established.
The objectives are the mutation of the strategy of the Member States regarding the NIP for influenza, including vaccine stocks, the publication of names, of
all the experts consulted by the European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media responsible for disseminating public health messages.
That is why it received our favorable vote.

Thank you, Mr President. To date, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been incorporated into Community legislation on a provisional basis, through annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These concern conservation measures, management, exploitation, control and marketing for fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of such a recommendation, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the recommendations in question into a single legislative act to which future recommendations can be added.
Today we have done this and it will improve legal certainty while constituting an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are required to ensure full implementation of the agreed measures, starting from the high stability.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty in the interest of all.

Mr President, I believe that the approval of my colleague Podima's report represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced, and stronger economic and fiscal policy in the European arena.

It is now clear to everyone that there is an urgent need for Europe, as a coordination between the 27 countries, to equip itself with economic and financial instruments capable of governing the economy rather than merely being subject to it.
For this reason, the proposal for a financial transaction tax has received a great deal of attention, sparked widespread discussion, and generated a lot of interest.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this rule is an important and significant event, because for the first time, things were not left to chance, and instead, a step forward was taken.
I hope that the Commission and the Council continue along this path.
I voted in favour of the reports on gender equality and female poverty in Europe and I am pleased that they were discussed today, on the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day.

Despite Directive 2002-73, which concerns equal treatment between men and women as regards access to employment, vocational training and promotion, and working conditions, further efforts are still needed to achieve proper implementation.

Suffice it to say that, despite the level of female education having increased significantly in recent years and the number of female graduates now exceeding that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female and often less remunerative sectors, and hold fewer positions of responsibility in all spheres of society.

The lack of access to care services for dependent persons, such as children, disabled persons and the elderly, to leave schemes that are appropriate to flexible work patterns prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by remembering the women around the world who are fighting for the most basic rights, and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, inviting women to demonstrate without the yellow headscarves.

I finally say that all the colleagues who have spoken are right to say that we must return to talking and I hope that we will soon return to acting, including with specific choices of economic policy and common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lang report, the excellent work done by my colleague, and the communication from President Tajani.

This choice means a few important things. First, the relaunch and recovery of the European economy and the maintenance of employment, as has been said, also lies, and perhaps above all, in the recovery and support of the entire system.
manufacturing sector, from the most advanced sectors to the more traditional ones, because there is a frontier that can still be tackled there, and this was not as obvious until a short time ago.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not at stake in the finance and service sectors, but still here, and it is not too late to do so, we can set a challenge for Europe to regain competitiveness with the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

Thirdly, it has been said that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, focusing on the factors and tools that can truly promote new businesses, new capacity for resilience and updating.

So I believe it is important to highlight these new factors that need to be addressed, as has been done. Credit: we are encouraging new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner on the subject of credit. Raw materials, energy costs, and immobility.
innovation, research, the need to enhance Europe's capacity to transfer the results of research and innovation into businesses, new products, and new production methods and organization.

We have to enhance a very distinctive fabric in our Europe, and in some countries in particular, that of SMEs, that of the quality of companies, the quality of products, in short, the distinctiveness of industry in Europe.
and I believe we should rediscover, let's say, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, in order to innovate and change them.
Finally, the theme of the territory is very important.
European policies are successful if they intersect and find a territory capable of addressing them.
So thanks to Lange and we have excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a short time.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles have yet to begin.
Today the urgency concerns women from other cultures living in Europe and the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this festival without placing the issue of women in the Arab-Muslim world at the center, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that concerns them today, but will soon become ours as well.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that are growing year by year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
Cases of violence of all kinds that Muslim women suffer within their own families have been on the rise for some time.

This is why I have been asking for some time, and I ask again today, that Europe implement targeted policies against the spread of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor killings, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We, European women and men, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only there, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic fundamentalism.

Thank you, Mr. President. I voted in favor of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform that took place last September 12th has been unanimously recognized as an important step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, there are still many steps to be taken, and I express my concern about the numerous arrests of journalists.

I emphasize that Turkey is the European Union's seventh largest trading partner, that the European Union is Turkey's main trading partner, and that trade, correctly interpreted for centuries, has fostered the interpenetration and peaceful understanding of peoples.

I therefore applaud the significant progress made in boosting connections between the European Union and Turkey, particularly those via the motorways of the sea crossing the northern Adriatic and northern Tyrrhenian Sea.
on which more than 250,000 trucks now move annually in both directions, in connection with an important rail link, which is a truck on a wagon, from port to European inland destination.
This has made it possible to eliminate a significant number of trucks on the road, and I hope that this trend will continue.
Mr President, with today's vote we have given a further boost to the definitive solution to this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to point out that the more than 300 amendments tabled in the report have been transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all of which have been adopted, and which aim to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, as well as the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, will have to ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and best practices. And the Member States should appoint an official, hopefully of a high level, from the Government who will act as a contact point for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more incisive and less hypocritical if in the report we had focused on the obligations and duties that the Roma community should still respect in the host countries.
This is my hope, that solutions will be found soon that allow for better coexistence of this community in all member states.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans that the island could never, ever accommodate.
Italy has been targeted for weeks by hundreds of dinghies carrying illegal immigrants.
And if we do not all react together, if the EU does not react, the wave of migration of people on the run will continue.
The illegal immigrants who arrived in recent months must be sent home. There is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond a few words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions. Where is Europe?
To date, Brussels has been cooperatively evasive, it has had a disgraceful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

However, Europe must not only help Italy with the repatriation of illegal immigrants, but also support the Italian government's efforts to prevent thousands and thousands of people from continuing to leave, especially from Tunisia.

A completely different situation applies to the Libyan refugees, on whom Europe must stand by Italy in the identification and logistical management operation, but above all must commit to ensuring that the refugees are hosted in all the member states.
The reception of those fleeing from war cannot fall solely on Italy.
It's time to stop talking.
The European Union, if it exists, must take action.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with illegal immigrants while France pushes them back with disgraceful methods.
Illegal immigrants must be sent back home, while all member states must commit themselves now to welcoming Libyan refugees.

Yes, Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, the issue of forecasting adequate financial resources to ensure the decommissioning processes of nuclear plants is a problem that has already been addressed by Adebit.
European Union legislation on nuclear safety is highly relevant today, in light of recent international events and the resulting decisions by EU governments on this matter.

The work of Mr. Marinesco, to which we have expressed our support, addresses the specific cases of certain countries that, at the time of their accession, assumed particular obligations regarding the decommissioning of nuclear facilities and that have received special support from the European Union precisely for this activity.
Beyond specific cases, it is imperative to establish effective verification and examination of nuclear power plants within the territory of the Union.
The number of reactors that are expected to be decommissioned in the near future within the Community territory appears to be high.
It will therefore be essential to ensure guarantee mechanisms, especially in these cases, for the allocation of adequate financial resources necessary to meet both ordinary and extraordinary needs.

We support an idea of the internal market that is capable of understanding and meeting social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.

This is present in today's texts.
There is recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, foundations, 10% of European companies and a large part of our employment.
they are real companies, demonstrating economic pluralism and business pluralism.

Beijing's justification that artist Ai Weiwei was arrested for economic crimes is unconvincing, and it is unconvincing that such harassment is being carried out against a free and dissident artist.

In the days when Arab uprisings are exploding, our thoughts go to the image of raw violence in Tiananmen Square against the young Chinese who, like today with the Jasmine Revolution, were demanding freedom and democracy.
China has opened up to the West economically, but without linking production to environmental protection and labor safety, and it fails to make any concessions to democracy and pluralism.
This is not an interference in Chinese internal affairs, as Beijing claims, but the appeal of men and women, movements, and parties who aim to build a world free from intolerance on every continent.

This is the disappointing balance in terms of impact on SMEs, in the failed Lisbon project, first, and in the carbon copy Europe 2020 strategy, on which it is even being decided to concentrate the resources of the next multiannual financial framework 2014-2020.

I can only reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are asking themselves: What is the point of Europe if it is unable to solve the continent's economic problems? Can it not speak with a single voice on foreign policy and squander money?
I hope that what Commissioner Tajani has said several times will come true.
I hope that the revision of the SME code will truly be able to simplify bureaucracy, ensure access and recovery of credit, and facilitate the intervention of action.
The directive on late payment represents a concrete and real achievement, but it is the result of political will rather than Euro-propaganda.

If the costs of yet another strategy will only fund more talk, I call on the European institution to make amends to the dozens of small entrepreneurs in my region, Veneto, who have taken their own lives before seeing their small business fail.

While Europe pretends nothing is happening, Europol's 2011 report on organized crime states that with the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, powerful criminal organizations from Turkey, Russia, and Albania will be able to expand their activities throughout Europe.
Furthermore, to quote verbatim, illegal immigration from Turkey will spread to the Bulgarian coast, and drug and human trafficking will increase, controlled by Turkish and Albanian criminals.

Furthermore, regarding human trafficking, Romania and Bulgaria's entry into Schengen could provide Bulgarian criminals and new Roma communities with new opportunities to increase their already significant trafficking activities towards the rest of Europe.
In the end, an increase in illegal immigration from Turkey and in drug and human trafficking, less security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do organized crime a big favor.
The Northern League party will always be opposed to this kind of reckless decision.
Those who vote in favor of this report tomorrow will bear the responsibility for a vote that will open up a highway for organized crime, leading straight to the heart of Europe.
Thank you, Mr. President. Thanks to the Treaty of Amsterdam, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater importance and the
The focus was on the integration between economic and environmental policy and on the inclusion of environmental issues in policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, as well as the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusion, invited the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the key aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favour of this proposed regulation because it creates new uses for national accounting data and for environmental statistics and for other statistical areas.

Thank you, Mr President. My vote in favour of the Garriga report on the European Union's forthcoming financial perspectives is based on the conviction that, precisely in one of the most critical moments,

For the so-called European spirit to be decisive, it is essential to insist on and prevail on the indispensability of providing credible instruments, starting with an adequate financial endowment for the Union.

Therefore, the request for an additional 5% for the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable for providing answers to the major issues before us. In fact, these resources are needed to

tackling real problems, such as stronger cohesion between the regions, greater capacity for research and innovation, and a stronger capacity to generate growth and provide employment. In fact, without resources

adequate, none of these problems will find a sufficient answer. Starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not harm the other existing categories.
That is why I voted in favour and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the recommendations in this report.

Thank you, Mr. President. The new Hungarian Constitution reduces the ability of oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court to intervene and increases the powers of the executive, thus challenging the normal balance of power.
Social rights are being stripped away, the state provides subsidies to those in need only if they agree to perform public works.
Finally, the right to self-defense is enshrined, allowing people to possess weapons at home even without a license.
The right to abortion is prohibited and strongly discriminatory rules are introduced against homosexuals.
This is contrary to Directive No 78-2000, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are poorly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
Honorable colleagues, we are about to vote on a strategic document of great importance that provides a solid framework for the negotiation on the financial perspectives for the post-2013 period.

starting from the demand for consistency between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called to play after Lisbon and in the face of the recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation that emerges from public opinion, from the recipients of EU policies, and from European social and productive forces.
We did it for cohesion, a crucial chapter in deciding what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
it tells us that cohesion is today a vital component of the European project, an important asset for everyone, to be safeguarded, protected, and renewed.

bridging internal gaps, making efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe even more important, fighting waste and clearly outlining the development policy.
And yet, I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with the safeguard clause is a challenge we must accept in order to open a new phase in politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to underpin the cohesion policy with the more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to ensure for Europe in the coming years.
I too would like to join in thanking Mr Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to put together this complex report.
I believe that what the Hon. Member pointed out is particularly important.
