The fundamental goal is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of
risk and speculation. When it comes to exchanging, as has happened, to insure 400 million dollars without collaterals, that is, without adequate reserves, one can understand the risks we are running.

That said, however, I would also like to touch upon two problems. The first problem is the relationship with the Council. The second problem is the organic nature of the proposal for the reform of financial markets that we must push forward.

I raise the first problem regarding the Council and I say it very clearly. The feeling is all too often that the Council represents an obstacle to doing things quickly and well in terms of financial market reform.
I hope that the new Presidency will take charge of this problem, because on this occasion too we must put into
I expect the process to take longer, largely due to the positions, difficulties, and conflicts that arise within the Council.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow.
The second issue, the organic nature and specificity of the measures.
It's not just the measure on OTCs, there's also the measure on short selling and other things.

I would like to highlight two points: the specific issue of the commodities market, a particular market that requires specific anti-speculative measures, and the problem of local authorities' exposure to derivatives in EU countries.
I think these are issues that Parliament must address.
Thank you, Mr. President. The Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences with the loss of radioactive water into the sea 6,500 times higher than the legal limits.
The risk of food products being contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this applies exclusively to fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly for canned fish.
We import 370,000 tons of canned tuna. The main suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is crucial and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the place where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to address this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not come into effect for another two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not be effective for another three years.
We must not create alarmist situations, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information,
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us hope. The hope is that the Polish presidency will contribute to the battle against the Europe of national egoisms.
national policies without a vision for the future, which would be a contribution to a Europe that truly thinks of itself as an integrated entity with a common destiny.
But, as you rightly said in your speech, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and solve.
In this short time, I want to point out two crucial issues on the economic and financial crisis front.
First issue. The reform of financial markets.
It is not a technical problem, it is a major democratic issue of our time. The timescales are too long. We need to resolve issues such as the reform of short selling and OTCs.
Second point. We are faced with the issue of taxing financial transactions. We need to get to the heart of the matter. We expect the Polish Presidency to make a concrete contribution in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the signing of the Schengen agreements.
No one disputes the advantages of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current system is no longer suitable for current and future needs.

For this reason, all Member States must commit to revising the functioning mechanisms of Schengen, so that freedom of movement does not come at the expense of our citizens' legitimate need for security.

As far as we know so far, the Commission's guidelines may also be partly acceptable, especially regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows states to temporarily reintroduce border controls in case of an emergency.
We must see, however, how this will happen and whether the statements will be followed by actions and, above all, concrete results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to address the general reform of the European border protection system, especially the external borders, where Frontex must become an agency with real powers of intervention and support for national authorities as soon as possible.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not want to merely survive.

The crisis has profoundly affected the real lives of European citizens and businesses and, if we do not react, risks irreversibly lowering the social and cultural quality, well-being, and future of young people and Europeans.

more than just values of cohesion and prosperity. Coming out of the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, which if necessary must also have their nails cut, by imposing strict rules on financial markets, remedies

against the recession, remedies against an unbalanced development model that has placed the person a step below profit, remedies against the resurgent nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that are its responsibility today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources, including new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, with research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure and work. Because without work, people are without dignity and without rights.

for industry operators and aims to establish high safety standards that will underpin the European Union's leadership in promoting the safety of offshore activities.

The single market, free movement, and the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have come into play regardless of a change in our way of legislating, in the European way and in the national way.

I would start right from our documents. I take this opportunity to suggest a kind of clarity test on our documents. When we make a white paper, a green paper, it must all be more understandable. And I would go so far as to say that the real and perhaps strategic proposal for our Europe and to really get this...

This virtuous phase of initiating legislation is to assign a specific delegation to a European Commissioner who specifically deals with clarifying legislation and the relationships between the States and Europe itself.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Mr Council representative and Commissioner, I would like to begin by welcoming, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved on 6 June last.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures on a European scale are needed to combat it.
According to Eurobarometer estimates, the vast majority of our European citizens believe that Europe must do more.
How to give them their due?

In many member states, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption. Suffice it to say that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it adopted by the Member States to date are insufficient to contain an expanding phenomenon.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is affecting people's lives, the stability of social security and welfare systems, and the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of 120 billion euros every year, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily deprives the Union and its Member States of resources.
they could be used to provide essential services, education, childcare, employment, transport, in short, to divert clean resources from supporting people.
We therefore need more courage and more firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by intensifying and toughening up anti-corruption measures at the Union level.

In particular, we cannot talk about fighting corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimum standards for defining the crime of corruption, which are not included in the package that has just been passed.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member countries, which is essential for preparing an effective response.
We are in favour, for example, of relaunching the network of anti-corruption contact points, as I proposed in the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not of yesterday, it has been existing for some years already.
Has the time perhaps come to critically assess the policies followed so far? Has everything always been done well?
We have always carried out appropriate analyses of the situation
Was the right approach chosen?
The same European Central Bank that, as Minister Rostovski says, saved Europe, has always done well even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates.
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of the markets and the slowness of politics. But is this the only problem?

Of course, if one considers that we are still in the implementation phase of July 21, this should at least suggest that we prepare and organize the summits and their conclusions better. But politics will always be slower than the markets.
So the point is to look further ahead, shifting the focus to fighting unemployment and development,

This is the ground that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on the indications of growth and development.

The Commission should go beyond its weakness, say that the priority is fighting unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth and a public investment strategy, while also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.
Mr President, I believe that the challenge for the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its first-grade status.
a world-class tourist destination and, at the same time, be able to enhance, both in terms of environmental protection and competitive capacity, all its territorial assets.

It is a challenging and unpredictable task, not only in light of the opportunities, but also of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani pointed out, it becomes crucial, as also noted in the Commission's opinion that we approved in the Committee on Regional Development,
to put together a strong overall strategy for the entire European Union on tourism, with an enhancement of the role of the regions and territories.
In this sense, full involvement from the outset is essential, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity of the Regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
I also believe the proposal to identify a European label capable of defining high quality in tourism products is a good one.
Obviously, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, especially from a financial point of view, to ensure that Europe's leadership is maintained in the future.

President, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the funding of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities that European development and economy have ahead of them.

It is indeed a matter of acting on the lever that can truly trigger a moment of growth and also of new skilled employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to the new opportunities of innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation that particularly emerges from this work is that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe research and innovation that lead to practical application.
to give birth to new companies, which come up with new patents and which do not remain purely basic research, pure knowledge, important yes, but not enough to really trigger the development bubble.

The second observation is the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial planning and for bringing together research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Thank you, Mr. President. The European schools were created with the aim of ensuring access to education in their mother tongue for the children of European institution agents who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg back in 1953 on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive impact of this form of education, as many as 14 European schools have been established within the various member states.

While recognizing that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present obsolete aspects and must in some way be adapted and adjusted to the new economic and social needs of Europe.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Mr Cavada, which calls for greater involvement of the European Union in supporting and coordinating the actions of the Member States, which are called upon to work towards developing and improving the European school system.
And investing, as we know, investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans. Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Mr. President. In recent decades, the number of natural disasters that have caused the death of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world has increased exponentially.

Thank you, Mr President, also for the recovery. Three brief points. We need more Europe here too.

More Europe means, for example, starting to really think about a common road police force, with identical rules in terms of protection and safety.

In relation to schools, in relation to young people, and also in relation to more at-risk groups, such as motorcyclists mentioned a moment ago, we could also talk about truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools within the machines that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-addiction tools.
I believe that this is a timely strategy to be developed with car manufacturers and European vehicle production.
Here, I believe that if all of this falls within the framework of a common policy, I truly think that perhaps conditions will improve.

The numbers, when viewed in their raw form, are very telling. The number of catastrophes in the world has quintupled. If we consider that in 1975
78 catastrophic events had been recorded, while today we have almost 400 calamitous events per year.

Unfortunately, in the last 20 years, the victims of these disasters have been 90,000 and more than 29 million people have been affected by the disasters, while the economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that require a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly strong commitment on our part.
We all have the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan etched in our minds.
Europe itself experiences sudden floods and fires on its territory every year, and we must not forget the ash cloud that followed the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.
There is no need to go further to assert how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
fundamental to us are our guiding principles: the principle of solidarity, which is reinforced by the solidarity clause in the Lisbon Treaty, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We are moving along these lines.
The European Union's intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as evidenced, I believe, by the work of our Commissioner Georgieva, but today we need to make a qualitative leap.
A qualitative leap that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to a response instead where the reaction...
it can be enhanced by the prior identification of existing resources in the Member States made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.

We hope that services like GMS will play a fundamental role in this coordination, and I take this opportunity to also express our concern about what is happening with the budget for these new technologies, which are crucial.

Oppressed ethnic minority, Christians forced to live in hiding their faith, priests barbarously murdered without the authorities lifting a finger. Anti-Western foreign policy, this is today's Turkey.
My party, the Northern League, has always been opposed to Turkey's entry into Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism on our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must call a definitive end to the accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must have an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to tell Europe what to do.
Cyprus is a full member of the EU and has the indisputable right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and show itself ready to defend Cyprus by any means in the face of Turkey's political and military arrogance and overbearingness.
Let us immediately halt the accession negotiations and be prepared to suspend trade relations as well.
President, we are experiencing a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, for the entire European project.
To have this awareness would mean to break free from a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological desire for budgetary austerity.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, we all want to reduce debt.
However, it is clear that without a smart investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
The only clear outcome of this approach is that, as always, the heaviest burden will be borne by the most vulnerable groups.
For this reason, together with the group of socialists and democrats, we voted against this report.
In fact, we continue in a single direction that is that of austerity without growth, a direction that has so far proved to be wrong.
The work done by my colleague Ferrera on this report is highly appreciated.
In fact, out of the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only this one did my group and I vote in favor of.

We did it because, among other things, a clause was included to protect social rights starting from collective bargaining, and there is also a strengthening of the role of Parliament in the adoption of delegated acts.

So, while we cannot change the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report certainly represents a step forward, providing, among other things, a surveillance system that takes fundamental rights into account.
And so, in this context, while we believe that a vision based solely on austerity policies does not produce positive results, this report certainly constitutes a positive note against the trend.

Esteemed colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken a stand in the Council for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are not currently able to guarantee effective border control and are plagued by rampant corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
This is not the view of populist movements, but of the airport in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

If Bulgaria were to join the Schengen Area at this time, police and security agencies predict that Bulgarian borders, especially the maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become a hub for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some member states have many reservations about the actual ability of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is a very strong migratory pressure from Turkey.
There are many reasons to oppose it, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I would therefore like to know what the Commission and the Council's intentions are regarding this sensitive issue, which in my opinion has so far been dealt with in a
and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in the field of security and international crime.

In my opinion, the Commission and the Council should postpone the entry of these two countries into Schengen and only give the go-ahead when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions on the security of European citizens.

Thank you, Mr. President. The crisis in Europe is entangling the problems of public budgets and private capital with those of the productivity of our companies in a vicious circle. And the specter of recession is there.
If, therefore, the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission that we must absolutely, together with Parliament, ensure that our good principles are put into practice.
and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice in the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Imagine, Commissioner, what would happen if all Member States were to bring forward the implementation of the directive against late payments? What a great advantage that would be for SMEs. So, SME evidence is important, but we are still at the methodological level.

Of course, it is right to check whether, when we legislate, we are really doing so in the interests and to the measure of small and medium-sized enterprises, but we ask that we proceed with great consistency and tenacity, let's say, in depth in creating this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
If we appreciate what the Commission is doing, we are ready to support it with the budget and with the other possibilities we have.
I'll just say a word about credit.
Let's have a clear discussion with the banks, I say to you, Commissioner, because we need to help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Thank you, thank you, Mr President. I cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague, Honourable Wallis.
while not prejudicing the usual means of access to justice, I am convinced that an alternative dispute resolution ADR represents a quick and economical alternative to legal disputes.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have significant development online for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through joint efforts with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens' confidence in the internal market, can help stimulate the European economy.

Mr President, honourable Members, the report on the provision for sectors placed on the market under the flexibility scheme, to which we have given our favourable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has

This is achieved, on the one hand, by avoiding the setting of unrealistic and impossible-to-meet requirements, and on the other hand, by establishing a so-called flexibility regime that is structured around the provision of time phases and corresponding quantitative limits.

The permitted emissions system provides for the release onto the market of a predetermined annual quota of tractors meeting certain characteristics, thus allowing the adjustment to the set standards to be spread out over time without causing trauma to the affected production and industrial sectors.

Honorable Tantarella, the work carried out has been important, he has managed to carefully balance the needs dictated by the major challenges that the European Union is called upon to face at this time and those of environmental protection and the current context of economic crisis.
Thank you, Mr. President. The current global economic crisis, even more severe than the one in 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade disparities between countries, financial markets lacking common rules, and instability in banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, which I support, urgently emphasizes the need for global economic governance and rules in the information age.

The economy needs a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter oversight policies. And the decision-making bodies, the international economic organizations, must be the main actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe specifically needs a transparent bailout to reduce the exacerbated stability issues also caused by globalization and ensure far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment and resolution that we emphasize to all countries.

Thank you, Mr. President. I voted in favor of the report by my colleague, Mrs. Matera, which analyzes the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as has already been mentioned, more than 5% of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text put forward today supports those policies that can provide concrete help for these women, such as, for example, facilitating...
healthcare, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access to affordable housing, and special unemployment benefits.
Only by adopting these measures can we meet the needs of an increasingly significant category in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Thank you, Mr President. The budget sets out a few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy. For this reason, I would like to thank the rapporteurs.
It is crucial to focus on investments and not just on prudent budget management.
The alternative would be to passively adhere to the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, cohesive entity ready for confrontation.

I welcome the commitments made on pilot projects and preparatory actions under heading 2, as well as the fact that funding for the integrated maritime policy does not come at the expense of other fisheries initiatives and programmes.

fish is considered a common good.
Thank you, Mr. President. The economic, financial, and social crisis we are experiencing has clearly highlighted several weaknesses in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most representative alarming data of the current situation is the almost 6 million jobs lost in the last three years, data that, as this situation continues, are destined to grow if we do not know how to react promptly and effectively.

The text by my colleague Bastos emphasizes that in order to make concrete progress, we need better energy, synergy between education, training, and the labor market, as well as a unified political approach aimed at ensuring a better match between the demands and supply of this market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I cast my vote in favor.
I cast my vote in favour of the motion presented by Mrs Angelilli because it addresses an issue that concerns me deeply as a mother and a grandmother.

Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse and the disgusting world of child pornography means defending our children and grandchildren, and consequently defending the weakest members of society.
Greater prevention, harsher criminal action against those who commit such crimes, and more careful protection of children: these are the key points of the document voted on today.
Without a doubt, the path is difficult.

I am thinking in particular of the spread of child pornography via the internet, which can only be combated through close cooperation between member states, police authorities and providers. Thank you.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the challenges posed by modernity and the report by our colleague Senator Fidina, to which we have given our favourable vote, require us to place the citizen in their role as a top-level consumer.

at the heart of the Community debate and remind us that the protection of its interests cannot remain merely a principle enshrined at the level of the Treaty, but must be a concrete guiding principle of European Union policies.

A protected and informed consumer, made more aware and therefore able to fully exploit the tools and resources at their disposal, able to fully exercise their rights, must be the ultimate goal of the European Union's new strategy for consumer policy.

Thank you, thank you, Mr. President. The phosphates in household washing machine detergents end up in European water systems, rivers, streams, and lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various life forms. Consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae robs other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins that destroy fish and plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text voted on today because in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent.

Mr President, the European Union has produced an enormous amount of laws, rules to build European law and has created the European area called the Stockholm Plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use that citizens make of it, which is numerically and percentage-wise very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the national lawyers of individual states, have grown up within the law of their own country and have a predominantly legal education in this regard.
While we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mindset and imbues himself with knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before discussing training, we must talk about extensive communication to citizens and legal professionals so that they become the bearers of this great innovation and increase the willingness to use the benefits of this right.

But above all, it is a grassroots movement that must be created in in-service training. You can't lecture like you would to schoolchildren when training adult professionals who are already highly qualified.

It is necessary to stimulate curiosity in dealing with one's own cases, to connect with other colleagues and to find solutions, since today Common Law and Civil Law converge, they are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects, in our Convention we are calling for a reversal of the trend, a bottom-up approach, with more legal studies than judicial training.
There is a very interesting example in Holland called Eurinfra, which is a network of officials in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to do the same.
Here is the essence of our project, and we hope it will receive full support from the Commission.

However, this is not enough. In a difficult time like the present, both economically and in terms of employment, communication, new technologies, and innovation are a primary asset that Europe must defend with more courage.
Every European citizen must be able to move freely between member states, using the telephone rate set by their national operator.

No more fraud and exorbitant bills for those traveling within the EU. If we really want to provide concrete support to citizens, let's create a kind of telecommunications Schengen, which no longer imposes different tariffs on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Thank you, Mr President. Colleagues, I was part of that delegation from the European Parliament that went to Sicily in November last year.
Our head of delegation Cecilia Wistrom wrote a letter to the Italian minister, the minister of the interior chancellor, and received a response that gave us fairly clear answers.

I would like to point out, above all, that after that visit to Italy, the government changed, and the approach to the situation also changed, but the situation itself in the countries from which the migratory flow predominantly originated also changed.
However, this should not distract us from the need for a careful analysis of what happened and also of the current situation.
The most relevant fact that is still relevant today is Lampedusa's status as an unsafe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contrade in Briacola following the fire of the
September 2011, which damaged it but only partially, namely a dormitory destroyed, one damaged out of seven buildings in the structure, and then the de facto suppression of the project

Now, apart from the consideration that in the Mediterranean the only unsafe port was that of Tripoli under Gaddafi, and I do not find this analogy flattering, given that the migratory flows, even if significantly reduced in number, also for seasonal reasons,

They have certainly not stopped. It is important that a first aid and reception service operates and functions in Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other side after journeys that are certainly not easy or risk-free. And the Somali shipwreck survivors who arrived in Italy know this well.
Thank you all.

And the Cala Creta Tourist Residence, where they are currently being held, is certainly not a CIE or a CARA, and above all, in the meantime, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything is entrusted to the goodwill and kind hearts of the carabineri on duty or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function that the center itself had assumed in the recent past.

Thousands and thousands of people were allowed to gather in a place that, due to its capacity and intended function, could only accommodate a few hundred people, and people who had never had the opportunity to be in such a large place, all in violation of legal and ethical norms.

The fact that a territory of just a few square kilometers, already difficult due to its location and logistical challenges, was forced to accommodate a number of people exceeding its own population, must be considered a significant turning point.
reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension that then escalated
to the fire itself.
I believe that my colleague Rinaldi's excellent report was successful in the Chamber.
I absolutely agree with Lusinghiero's assessment of the report.

Nevertheless, I would like to raise a small issue. Our Europe, in relation to this new world that is trying to find democracy and different economic conditions, is a Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely a particular attention to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to focus on, both with regard to environmental aspects and with regard to economic transactions that are in the Mediterranean.
fishing spot medrano
We are building a new fisheries policy in Europe that will set very strict rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules there.
So why not use forms of fisheries agreements, support for these countries so that those countries apply the same rules that apply in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fisheries, it would be beneficial for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure that this divide becomes less and less of a divide, and more and more a homogeneous place upon which to build the future of Europe and of this new world.

As envisioned in the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament has become a full-fledged institutional actor in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to actively and decisively participate in setting the priorities of the internal security strategy and the security model of the Union.

The report by my colleague Borsellino identifies five key areas for which concrete actions have been proposed and calls for greater judicial and police cooperation between member states to combat organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to strongly consider the development of prevention policies, which are fundamental tools for ensuring a European area of freedom, security and justice.
President, with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the foundations have been laid for the development of integrated criminal law within Community law.

While recognizing the importance of mutual recognition and harmonization of protection standards, and the principle of the presumption of innocence, it is important to emphasize that the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable, so that everyone knows what constitutes a crime and what does not.
This is particularly true for directives that must be reciprocal to national law.
Any lack of clarity could, in fact, give rise to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent European strategy of quality in the field of criminal law.
Thank you, Mr. President. The European Union guarantees the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising, and abusive contractual clauses.
I have no doubt that those consumers who are more vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health problems, or simply due to a lack of proper information, must be protected more carefully.
I therefore cast my vote in favour of the test by my colleague Mrs Perez because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer rights
The so-called most vulnerable, contribute not only to their social inclusion, but also to ensuring a single market that is safer, fairer and more competitive.
Yes, Mr. President, the report by my colleague Perez, to which we cast our favorable vote, addresses the need to consider the development of a
strategy aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in view of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
The conditions of consumer vulnerability arise due to various factors and can potentially affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside the general protection of consumers, and to develop a targeted strategy in this regard that takes into account the complex nature of the problem while avoiding

on the one hand, the formulation of static definitions is rigid and unable to consider all the facets of the issue and the different possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other hand, it prevents the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protective measures.

Thank you, thank you President. The management of bluefin tuna fishing has a long, rather complex history, dating back to the 1990s, and is currently probably the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite substantial investments in monitoring having led to greater compliance with regulations, there are still concerns about the problem of overfishing.
I therefore expressed my support for the Romeva-Irueda report, which proposes a reduction in the allowable catch rate, greater control, and the strengthening of measures to reduce capacity.
The relationship between the European Union and China clearly shows imbalances at the trade level.
It is therefore incumbent upon European institutions to strive to help European businesses emerge from the crisis and succeed in making access to international markets more equitable.
I therefore expressed my support for this report, particularly highlighting among the issues raised by the rapporteur the application of the principle of reciprocity to relations.
relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition in international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Thank you, Mr. President. The road is still long, but today's decision can be an important step towards the introduction and application of a financial transaction tax.
I understand the prudence, caution, and need for gradualism expressed by Commissioner emeta, as well as the technical problems rightly discussed by Minister Vestager.

But precisely for this reason, I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to provide impetus and drive to the necessary initiatives to address the problems that still remain unresolved, especially at the Council level.
We all want to carefully assess the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic behind the proposal for exemptions.
if you are concerned about reducing the impact of the tax, then it is important to have a tax base as broad as possible, with a low rate, and not to try to extend exemptions indefinitely.

For those concerned about the impact on small investors, I would like to remind them of the progressive nature of the tax, which means that those who carry out more transactions are taxed more heavily.
transactions and it is clear that the competent authorities will in any case have to ensure that attempts are not made to pass on any costs to customers and end-users.
I therefore hope that Parliament will vote in favour of this tax by a large majority.

Thank you, Mr. President. Since 1990, through the instrument of macro-financial assistance, the European Union has been providing economic aid in the form of grants, loans, or a combination of both, to countries experiencing difficulties with their balance of payments in the short term.
The rather long timeframes, added to the difficulties revealed by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to formulate some changes to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make the evaluation criteria faster and more effective, and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Thank you, Mr. President. There are approximately 100 million European citizens engaged in various volunteer activities.

From major sporting events to cultural events, the role played by volunteers is crucial, and we must not overlook the work of those people who rush to provide help and solidarity in the event of serious natural or environmental disasters.
Volunteering constitutes one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I expect the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the removal of the existing obstacles.
Thank you, Mr. President. From the communications sector to finance, transportation, energy, culture, and health, the role played by technology is becoming increasingly relevant.
The increasing use of the Internet and digital media makes the problem of cybersecurity one of the priorities on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed promote economic and social development only if the existing regulations guarantee user security with regard to data privacy and intellectual property rights.

For this reason, only full international cooperation involving states, members, institutions, and industry can give rise to a robust system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Thank you, Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, you have said important things, and very shareable ones at that.
I find it truly, as he said, shocking that we have each lived in our own country with the numbers and figures that we heard earlier from our colleague Oconi.
But it is equally evident that this scandal has really highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of the European legislation currently in force on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the shortcomings we have discussed in this Chamber, which the Commissioner has so well represented, so I would not like to dwell on this aspect in the short time available.
I believe it is important to put everything in place so that we can offer the best to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so much, could also be an opportunity to take a further step forward. I would like to build on what my colleague said earlier.

The communication made to patients is really poor, it always only emphasizes the positive aspect, it says that there is a kind of eternal youth, of promised beauty, there are no prostheses that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when it comes to pure cosmetic surgery, must be truly communicated to people, to girls, because we know that there are very young girls who are approaching this type of procedure.
So I see that you are absent with conviction, so I recommend, let's really work, time is short, we should have already done it yesterday.
Thank you, Mr President. The Council regulation on the multiannual plan for the stock of blue whiting was adopted before the Treaty came into force, and therefore alignment was necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could influence the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
That is why it is often my vote in favor. Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, thank you, Mr. President. From Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, numerous environmental disasters have struck Europe in recent years, putting the health of European citizens at risk.

The text by my colleague Ader concerns the revision of the Service 2 directive, which aims to mitigate the effects of accidents involving significant quantities of dangerous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations that will come into effect from June 2015 are aimed at protecting the environment and, above all, at limiting tragic consequences for citizens' health. And so I cast my vote in favor.
Thank you, Mr President. I too would like to thank Mr Stevenson for the excellent work he has done and the approach he has taken in this report, which essentially addresses the two main issues.

This is not just about a simple herring management plan, it is essentially about ensuring a future for fishermen in some respects and planning in the sea to ensure that it has its own protections over several years.
But the key point of this report is and remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council must accept the approach given by the Lisbon Treaty and I also think that the time has come for Parliament, in some way with a perhaps more authoritative voice than that of the
debate within the Committee on Fisheries or a debate on a report concerning hake has the courage to take a very clear and strong position on the issue of delegated acts.
We demand the right for these matters to be handled through the ordinary procedure.

So perfectly that the issue also involves, in addition to many other sectors of fishing, which will incidentally worsen with the ongoing reform, but it concerns issues related to agriculture and other topics.
The essential point is to respect the will of Parliament.
In drafting this report, no account was taken of the parties directly concerned, the road haulage companies.
In Italy, 91% of freight transport is carried out by road.
Their rights will be ignored if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we work daily to reduce the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like these undermine our efforts.
all our efforts, because they will suffocate companies themselves with new bureaucratic burdens, with ruinous economic losses and with new forms of unfair competition.
It would have taken little to achieve a balanced report that did not forget the survival crime of our companies in a very difficult economic period. But a dialogue of this kind was not possible.

On the contrary, the report deliberately ignored even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 Working Time Directive. It even ignored European Commission documents, which acknowledged the dangers of practices like retrofitting, which is instead being proposed again in this report.
The document we will vote on tomorrow, colleagues, will ask you to forget the positive achievements made in recent years, and once again it will be European companies that will foot the bill.

Just to say, Mr. President, that Acta was a very serious political mistake. Let's leave aside the legal one. It has caused a reaction in the world of immense proportions and this is enough to say that it is a political mistake.
Why the bence?
Why did it create the suspicion that access to the web, which is a great modern revolution, would really be closed off?
And why is that?
because he made the mistake of lumping together counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinctly different phenomena
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.

And then there was another mistake that excluded Parliament from an important activity it has been carrying out for some time, which is to create a new copyright. Now, this, while some would like to preserve the

old copyright that existed before the web. So, the point is that we need to work on copyright and set aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and reject it and exclude it, because it is an obstacle to our work.

Fortunately, after months and years of hesitation, the Commission has brought two important measures, orphan works and the upcoming one on copyright management companies, to the attention of the Green Parliament.
This is the advantage. But we work on this by reflecting with our brains and not just with our emotions, but without having any cards up our sleeves.
Thank you, Mr President, just to add my voice to the plaudits that this report has received in the Chamber regarding the need to strengthen the capacity of the European Union.
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce and manufacture in line with our vision of an inclusive, socially and environmentally sustainable economy.

So I believe that some of the guidelines here are very useful in this measure, others can be added, and I think it's important to gather this information, to work more and more to ensure that the attractiveness is the
the consequence of territorial policies, territorial marketing, and openness, whereby the territory proposes a productive and industrial vocation,

service manufacturers that, emerging from the territory, respect all environmental compatibility factors. And together with European policies that go in this direction, from the territory and from Europe, a voice that is attractive for investments and growth.

Thank you, Mr. President. When we discuss sensitive issues such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic production, we are talking about the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is important to meet consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets, and it is also important to ensure proper implementation of Community legislation by the authorities, bodies, and operators concerned.
For this reason, I cast my vote in favor of my colleague's text.
The history of the first comments on the Council has now entered the phase of reductive reading, and this is wrong because important steps forward have been made.
Consider, for example, the breaking of destructive ties between banks and public debt, the weak employment plan.

The spirit of relaunch and a renewed path of political unity seems to be returning to the European institutions, after so much slowness and torpor, and a desire for real progress towards greater integration.
and we have seen strong unity between Parliament and Commission on this.

I am not talking about winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis, of the community spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from multiple countries, not to create new exclusive axes, but to build a common consensus that respects all member states.
This is the path of the political goal of unity, without which any banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be completely insufficient.
In June, with the Council's decision to give member states the option to reintroduce border controls, a new Europe was born, a Europe that was brave enough to fulfill the desire of its people.
greater security for its citizens, finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, which is reduced to the defense of the rights of its peoples above all else.

To President Schulz, even though he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an interinstitutional incident, but rather respect for the will of the citizens and not that of the Eurocracy, which for years has pretended not to understand what is really happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of illegal immigrants, Mr. President Schulz, but a 35% increase in illegal immigrants, as measured by Frontex, in 2011.

My only concern is that the scenes of political grandstanding played out at this last plenary session have taken time away from a more useful and constructive activity: questioning why it was not we who defended the interests of our citizens, but rather the Member States.

If Parliament does not find its soul and the courage to go against the feel-good approach, the sterile platitudes on which it has been floundering for too long, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.
Mr President, I wish to draw the attention of this House to the fact that yesterday was
officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
The particle that gives mass to all the others is their existence and this happened on European soil.
Science gives life to our land, civilization, and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to return to being a world science capital.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wants to realize it. And it is for science and for this wonderful ambition of man that today a person
A blind girl who lacks eyes can see with her hands or read a book with her ears, and a young South African boy who lacks legs can run in the Olympics in a speed competition.
Well, Europe must be the homeland of science. This great event that will open new frontiers to knowledge must be fully supported by Europe.
Thank you, Mr. President. All too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not report crimes due to fear or lack of trust in the institutions.
The text voted on today aims to strengthen the rights of crime victims and ensure they receive the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice in all cases.
all EU countries, paying particular attention to those victims who are at a high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Of particular importance is the recognition of victim status not only for those who have suffered prejudice as a result of a crime, but also for family members and the deceased as a result of the crime.
On September 11, the Catalan people demonstrated peacefully in Barcelona.
One million people have called for Catalonia's independence from Spain.
On October 15, last Monday, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow the referendum for Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in recent weeks thousands of people have signed to hold a referendum for the independence of Veneto from Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, in Lombardy and in all the northern regions, hundreds and thousands of people signed to have more autonomy from Rome.
But also in the Basque Country, citizens are clamoring for autonomy and independence from nation-states.
And what does President Schulz say?
it takes a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy, Vidal Quadras, even worse, has called for the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are a most serious act, contrary to the principles of the democracy that we preach here and that we must defend.
I tell them that it will be the people who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats in Brussels.
The path is already mapped out.
The austerity policy adopted to overcome the economic crisis has not yielded the expected results.
as was emphasized in the report by my colleague Lavia, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget aimed at
by supporting growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economy of the member states and improve the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I therefore cast my vote in favor.
Thank you, Mr President. The social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is quite problematic.

With member states engaged in making fiscal adjustments to their national budgets to redress public finances, the European Union is seen in some cases as an entity that increases the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, in order to truly emerge from the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of training and development.
This is the charter of an institution. The budget reveals what it is, what it does, and above all, what it wants to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice, between a budget of survival, of dragging things along, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments for employment, for innovation, for young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

Everyone should understand that, as my colleague Calfin, among others, has made very clear, Europe can do today what the states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories, where social cohesion is established or the lives of the citizens we have discussed are destroyed.
Europe's major decisions are now at risk of being stifled by the bureaucratic disputes within the Council, and not only between beneficiary countries and paying countries.

We say that it is a false problem because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, for what has happened in the past, that contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working on putting figures next to the various headings.

The war of positions has begun, with declarations and statements from certain states that view the budget as just another item of expenditure, which can be cut without remorse, and which may even serve to bolster anti-European sentiment, which is easy to stir up in times of economic crisis.
It is a wrong position that does not help that integration that we are trying to achieve in other areas.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as many of us have said.
We adopted a stability pact, which was also meant to be a development pact, but we have become so stable that we are now in recession.
Here, let us at least take the opportunity of this budget, of this multi-annual framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Thank you, Mr. President. The lack of information and awareness about one's rights, combined with obstacles,
Language problems and the non-recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common issues that EU citizens encounter when residing, studying or working in another European Union country.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility of the notion of Union citizenship and its concrete benefits.
This is why I expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to strengthen awareness of the rights associated with citizenship of the Union, to help citizens fully exercise their right to move and reside freely within the territories of the Member States.
President, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance, and monitoring their effectiveness.
In fact, it is necessary to find a fair balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level is, however, of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investment in the economy.
in a manner consistent with its own objectives, in a context where the continuous decrease in responses to the Community budget is juxtaposed with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
The Brussels I Regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts
of Union legislation, as it has laid the foundations for a European judicial area that promotes and ensures legal certainty among European citizens.
The recast of this regulation addresses fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules on...
on the jurisdiction of disputes with parties domiciled in third countries and agreements on the choice of jurisdiction.
I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can ensure stronger consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, which is why I cast my vote in favor.

Commissioner, today you have called on Europe to take on a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most ardent supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without greater Europeanization of national strategies, including in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The car crisis is not just about overproduction capacity, it's about a dramatic loss of jobs.
But the crisis now seems structural and concerns the very fate of the car, of the product, as it is today.
We want to secure the car industry in Europe and we do not want to squander the skills, the existing know-how, the professional expertise.
We therefore call for the launch of a major restructuring and relaunch project, and for this to be done quickly, because the costs are proportional to the time taken.
Restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or individual company actions alone.
At the very least, we must attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties together through social dialogue.
producers, trade unions and individual country governments, providing support for research, innovation, human capital formation, retraining, and the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult task because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have effective community impetus and guidance to face the increasingly aggressive global market together.
The energy crisis has cost and is costing dearly in terms of employment, affecting thousands of precarious workers, as well as stable and temporary workers who are numerous in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly orienting themselves towards the Far East or the American continent, which poses a major question about the direction of our development model.
I think that Europe must recover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic production capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, and we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to stop industrial decline.

And I believe that we must also move away from a dualism that is not being discussed here tonight, but that is often heard in discussions about this sector, a dualism between environmental supporters and workers, which is wrong because it does not allow us to see a future perspective.
An industry that sees steel production as an integral part needs advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard different interests and diverse needs.

Therefore, a strong planning approach is needed, including at the European level, that focuses on sustainability, which, in my opinion, we must not abandon, as it is a valuable added asset with which we want to compete in the world, supporting investments, as has been said.

As has been said on many occasions, new technologies and new processes are needed to upgrade plants for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, indeed starting with energy resources, and also in the search for new and different materials.

Yes, thank you, Mr. President. As we have mentioned in this Chamber, next December, the United Nations Agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, and I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words, the work that has been done to date, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed by another authority.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of states from all over the world are part, and many of which are known for problems related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
So it is not wrong to believe that the pillars of the Internet, namely freedom, participation, openness, and innovation, are in danger.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet and the role that the Internet can play in relaunching economic growth, but not only that, also to ensure opportunities for everyone.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards the goal of Europe and Dubai being united and speaking with one voice.

Many controversial proposals were presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, particularly those that envisage changes to Internet governance, which call into question net neutrality with negative repercussions for consumers.
At risk, therefore, is the freedom of the Internet or, more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection.
What some states have proposed would indeed allow a government to stick its nose not only into the communications of its own citizens, but even into the data that flows through its own networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression and censorship is extremely short and therefore I believe it is in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. I have expressed my support for my colleague's text. In particular, I agree with the rapporteur in emphasizing the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training in the field of jurisdiction for legal, judicial and administrative authorities for legal professionals.
All sector initiatives should also be intensified in order to fully realize the concept of a Union based on the rule of law.

Thank you, Mr. President. In recent years, the extraction of hydrocarbons, the so-called unconventional ones, including shale gas and oil, has led to an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to cope with this situation and be less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore have to rely on its potential gas and oil reserves.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized the exploration for shale gas and are preparing for the extraction phase if the discovery allows it.
In such a context, it becomes necessary to monitor the regulations concerning the extraction of shale gas within the borders of the Union, so that the effects of its
without a doubt valid from an economic standpoint, do not create environmental problems due to the possible release of harmful substances into the groundwater or the atmosphere.
Thank you, Mr. President. I believe that today's meeting should be an opportunity to objectively discuss the important agreement that Kazakhstan is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country for the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is an indisputable important economic and trade partner of the European Union.

This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but which still needs to make a great effort to bring these processes to a successful conclusion.

However, it is a country that, with this objective, persists in demonstrating its readiness for new and more robust reforms, and I believe that it is the task of the European Union to accompany these reforms.

For this reason, I am certain that the signing of this enhanced agreement will allow for progress, as its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure ongoing assistance from the European Union.

I also remain convinced, and I believe this should have been even more emphasized in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that the improvement of progress on the path to democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and mutual commitment to open and constructive dialogue.

Our goal should not be to confront these and other countries in negative terms over the immediate implementation of changes. Our goal should be to support these countries' efforts to achieve the goal of respecting human rights principles as well.

Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the reports we will be voting on tomorrow. Just a brief point on the split vote, and I endorse what I have heard this evening as the unanimous voice of all my colleagues.
But I wanted to focus on artisanal fishing, on the Ferrera report, which I welcome and congratulate him on.
I wanted to say one thing: the past common fisheries policy has only contributed to increasing the gap between the institutions that regulate fishing and its stakeholders, that is, the fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing in Europe has penalized those who have always viewed fishing as an activity tied to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption from the ban on removing shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further ensuring that sharks receive the protection they need, will thus enable the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world as well.
